reviewText:
PewDiePie: The legend of the Brofist is pretty co- No I'm lying, it's not cool at all.

Remember back in the day when controllers had like, three buttons and roughly the same amount of pixels? Remember those really weird marketing games that came out like McKids and CoolSpot and that one game about the noid? This is essentially the modern day version of that.

You play as Felix Arvid Ulf Kjellberg, a Swedish man who, like me, enjoys yelling at children. But unlike me, Felix gets paid to do so. Suddenly, Felix's home is attacked by...Barrels for some reason and apparently all those kids he likes to yell at were kidnapped. Now, Felix is forced to go on an adventure where he meets people I don't know while making jokes I don't understand so he can save kids I don't like while fighting an enemy I don't care about. Also, he has two dogs that I sacrifice for my own gain on a regular basis.

PewDiePie: The legend of the kidney stones is a 2d side scrolling adventure that will take you around 3 hours to finish. The gameplay is as simple as moving forwards and then jumping with two buttons for powerups that aren't very good. At first, I thought the game was kind of fun, but the longer the game went on and the further I got, Felix's slidey and floaty jumping really got on my nerves. It feels unresponsive and clunky once there are more than three things to dodge on screen.

Now, I will admit, I enjoyed myself for a total of twenty minutes. before all of it got on my bad side. This game made me itchy if that made any sense.

I did not finish PewDiePie: The legend of the wasted lunch money, and I have no intention of ever finishing it. I got to the last boss and that was it for me, I had no intention of finding out what happens at the end. I'd ask who this game is for but there are roughly 40 million people subscribed to the Youtube account so I guess that question is already answered for me.

Should you play: PewDiepIe: The legend of the ♥♥♥♥thisgame?

I honestly don't even know how to make this review entertaining, I'm pretty much just rambling and hoping all of this makes sense, I don't know it could be the huffed paint talking.

Don't play this game unless Felix is your surrogate best friend, I got it as a gift from a friend and he is currently clawing at the inside of a coffin desperately gasping for air at the bottom of a lake.

Pewdiepie doesn't get a score, no, I'm not doing it, you can't make me. I'm sure this scathing review will hurt Felix plenty, he can cry himself to sleep on his bed made of money.

You get nothing out of nothing.

I'm going to go stare at a wall and think about Robocop for a few hours.

reviewText:
GameplayThe gameplay is fun for only a short while, and gets boring quite quickly. Fortunately, as you progress through the levels, you unlock new abilities which add some variety. The characters usually only have 1 difference, (gameplay wise) and that's their abilities. Collecting all of the patches was an easy challenge except for a few, so the game is quite easy. (except on pug mode)

GraphicsThe game's graphics are quite appealing and use pixel graphics, simple enough for the game to run well, and the art's good enough for you to distinguish between the characters. It's very colourful and only a few levels had boring designs. (such as the caves)

Final ThoughtsThe game is quite enjoyable and runs well, with appealing graphics as well. However, the game is quite short with repetitive levels and only harder difficulty modes and co-op options for thosewho want to continue playing the game. Most of the humour is quite childish and will only be enjoyed or understood by pewdiepie fans. The voice acting is quite bad, despite that most of the people in the game have done skits or similar things before.
The game gets a 7/10 but with price tag of £5.60 and the story being as short as it is it is hard to recommend.

Buy it when it's on a sale for about 50% less or more, and it's worth getting, just don't buy it if you don't like the guy because then it'll be the biggest cringe-fest on the internet.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Bm3WYzaqsQ

Many have heard about Pewdiepie and either adore him or dislike him fueled by personal reasoning, whatever the excuse, Pewdiepie is a renowned “Let’s Play” YouTuber with the largest subscriber count to date and now a game to add to the fame. The game lets the player take the role of Pewdiepie, along with other Let’s Players associated with him, to venture through tedious, platforming landscapes to rescue Pewds fans from the grasps of the relentless and evil Barrels. The game plays like a standard platformer adding other intriguing retro style elements similar to Gradius on the NES to make a bit of variety, which keeps the game interesting.

What I liked:

Quirky Opponents - While playing the game one sudden realization surfaced: this game is in no way meant to be taken seriously, not even the slightest. After all, the title pays homeage to Pewdiepie’s quirky, online behaviour. The levels are littered with an assortment of random enemies, each one harboring their own unique way of harming you. Most enemies are a variation of barrel characters ranging from regular barrels, who just hop ever-so-closely in hopes of inflicting damage, to TNT barrels that simply explode when you come into close proximity to spray you with harmful debris. While you may think about the oddity of such opponents, things get more peculiar as you witness killer whales falling from the sky and mystical unicorns charging at you with their rainbow entrails. Like I said, the enemies get interesting and/or ridiculous, which is amusing a lot of the time.

Skills or Just Difficult- Platforming is a skill that wasn’t ever weaved into my DNA so it all depends on the player and their level of expertise that will determine the punishment of this game. For someone like myself (who lacks basic platforming skills) they might find the easy mode option appropriate for beating the game, while those who do require a challenge to fully prove themselves can do so. The players can choose between easy, medium and hard which are represented by icons referenced from Pewdiepie’s videos. Depending on each difficulty, opponents can inflict more damage and spawn numerously while levels add environmental dangers to keep you on your toes. Although there was trouble with this, it was appreciated that each level of difficulty was  appropriately tedious.


It’s the Personality and Attacks- When you start the game, players are given the option to select between Pewds and Marzia as their controllable protagonist. As you progress further into the game other YouTubers become available for purchase for a set fee. Upon unlocking them, you can then upgrade their health with in-game currency as well as acquire desirable attacks and defences, however, each character has a designated attack that is tailored to their individualistic attributes. It makes it intriguing but doesn’t necessarily give the player the advantage as each character is limited to one attack and defence move at a time.

What I disliked:

Storytelling-  As stated earlier, this game honestly does not merit a serious reaction. The voice acting is respectively performed by the actual YouTubers themselves and unfortunately sounds more awkward than they probably initially planned. Each sentence was often read with such a dull, monotone rhythm and lacked any excitement, making the storytelling lackluster and forgettable. Then again, the story is overly simplistic since all you’re doing is rescuing the viewers from evil Barrels.

Controls-  For most platformers, gameplay mechanics aren’t usually in-depth and complicated. Playing each level should be smooth and with quick ease, however, the controls for this game, even though simple, feel deliberate and awkward at times.  In-game, you have the typical jump with an added bonus of an attack and defence ability. Although the title has these added attributes, controlling the character feels sluggish at times. It also doesn’t help that there is only one default speed implemented in the game. It would have been better to have a sprint like in Mario games.

Over Referenced- The game has a substantial amount of references that will be lost on those who aren't familiar with Pewdiepie’s content. A lot of the images and story plot is ridiculously random just to fit in with the references.

Conclusion: Pewdiepie: The Legend of the Brofist is definitely a game for fans because they’ll appreciate the many odd jokes referred in the game. The game had an interesting concept of adding attack and defence abilities but overall gameplay felt slow and sluggish.

Score: Wait for a sale

reviewText:
It's not the next Braid, but mechanically it's a decent game. There's not much to fault it for other than being short and the over-the-top fan pandering which, as indifferent, I found to generally be off-putting or not make sense (a rock named Jennifer?), but at the same time I commend it for aiming to please and be memorable to its fans rather than something generic. Needless to say if you despise the guy then you'll despise this game.

Pros:
-It has a nice high-res pixel art aesthetic, looking something like an HD GBA game.
-The music is pretty great. It sounds like it's going for an NES style and comes off as authentic to me.
-Fully voiced, though you may consider that a con as they're not voice actors by trade.
-Collectibles and unlockables to give you stuff to do while/after beating the game. The collectibles are put into tricky-to-reach or hidden areas throughout the levels.
-There are a number of small touches that make it feel like a polished game with care put into it. Picking up hearts when your health is full turns them into coins so they're not a waste. Changing your costume changes the character portrait in cutscenes. Replaying a level with an unlocked character changes things if that character normally appears in the level. There's a level where you get picked up in a helicopter to escape and if you try to enter it from the top or rear, jumping through its blades, you get chopped to bits as Mark screams Noooooo". It caught me totally off guard and I couldn't even be mad because it was hilarious.

Cons:
-It's short. There are 27 levels total and if you just do a single playthrough and don't worry about collectibles/unlockables or the 7 optional levels then you'll only get a couple hours out of it.
-Too easy on any difficulty less than "Bro"

reviewText:
Well this is a game I really didn't expect to be any good considering who it's based on and considering there there are no realy quality fangames for this particular LPer.
But I was pleasently surprised.

The game itself is pretty short, just under three hours if you play every level on easy mode.  However for those three hours you get a lot of content.  Multiple characters (of which I mainly used one when I unlocked him),  Different attack and defense abilities which I only used a couple because all the rest just didn't seem that useful.  And of course extra stages that unlock costumes.

The graphics are nice and mesh well together with the exception of the potrait shots during dialog sections,  they kinda look like crap.  The voice acting in most parts needs a bit of work and feels stilted but for some characters gets better as the game progresses, with the exception of Marzia's who I found annoying, but then again I didn't use her at all because outside of being the player two character for local-coop just didn't bring anything to the table except be annoying whenever she came up.

This game clearly had a lot of care put into it and there is a whole bunch small details such as the way certain items interact with the environment, character costumes are reflected in the cutscenes and loading screens with one costume for pewdiepie tying a certain scene together making it all the more hilarious as it goes on.

But I will admit I actually didn't play as the pewsdter as soon I was able to unlock and play as the lper I like more,  I totally skipped Marzia without even bothering to buy her.  The others I touched upon on my stream of the game just to show them off.
All said this was a neat little game and you get a whole lot for a mere six dollars.  and believe me I've played far worse games that had this price tag.  I'm looking at you Banzai Pecan.
Anyhoo I hope this helps with your decision on whether you want to get the game or not.

reviewText:
This game is absolutely nonsensical. I mean, maybe there's some lovely tapestry of narrative in it, but if I have to go watch a youtube dude to figure it out, you haven't told a good story. But you don't play this for the story (dear god I hope you don't, anyway). This game is a pretty open love letter to the 16-bit era slathered in a layer of surreality, and it actually plays damn well. Most levels basically spelled out their intent or were based on something I recalled from my younger days, and while I think one or two stages' gimmicks make their lack of checkpointing* irritating, only the rather-lengthy final boss really held me up for more than 15 minutes. It's also got a bunch of difficulty settings in case you find it too simple/challenging, and after you beat the endboss you can play anything you've beaten on Hard on a one-hit kill, no powerup mode, should you be masochistic enough.

I really wish cutscenes were skippable, but aside from that, this was actually real fun to fiddle with for a few nights.

* The game does feature checkpoints. Just not on some levels, which tend to be non-standard.

reviewText:
PewDiePie: Legend of the Brofist is actually a very well-made and fun game.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o9o12p2blPQ
I personally don't enjoy PewDiePie's content. He seems like a nice guy, but his videos simply don't entertain me, so I'll be reviewing this strictly on how good it is as a game.

The game obviously has a lot of inside jokes that fans of PewDiePie will get more out of than I did. The weakest part of the game was the dialogue. Not to say that it's awful or anything, but it was nothing special, and not too funny.
However, the animations, sprites and gameplay were funny, so it was fine.

The game is more fun with a friend in co-op, although doesn't make much of a difference. Most of the levels comprise of the basic platformer rules. Jump onto enemies to kill them, although there are some levels that shake things up a bit like a side scrolling plane shooter.

The gameplay stays fresh by allowing you to purchase new characters and powerups with the money you've earned throughout levels.

Overall, the gameplay doesn't feel incredibly unique or anything. It's simple and mostly sticks to what has worked in most platformers, but it does it all well! It's a pretty fun game.

This is, surprisingly enough from all the negative reviews, a fun platformer. Now, first thing, if you don't like PewDiePie, why are you even here? A lot of the dislike for the game seems to come from one of 3 things, 2 of which are reasonable.

1. Bad experience with bugs and glitches. I have yet to encounter any myself, but a player should always be wary of such.

2. Dislike of the quality. Completely understandable. The voice acting is not that great, and the platforming is rather simple. Don't expect Super Mario or Shovel Knight from this gam (not that the others were, or anything). This seems to be a rather simple game specially crafted for fans of Felix and his friends.

3. This is the unreasonable one. Some people seem to have purchased this game with the intention of giving it a negative review because they don't like the man whose name is plastered on the title screen. They feel the need to insult their peers for enjoying PewDIePie's content, as it's not suited to them. If you're one of those people, there is NO NEED to temporarily spend your money, but instead just do it in a comment section or something for virtually free.

Through my small amount of gameplay so far, I'd say that only if you're a fan of Felix and co. then go right on ahead and buy. If not, maybe take a small dip and see if you'll enjoy it for the simple game that it is. Hey, maybe you'll find a new source of entertainment from the content creators included. Or the duck. You can always like ducks.  And if you hate him for whatever reason, I beg that you spend your time and money doing something more worthwhile, like charity or children. Please?

Personally, as an on and off fan, I'd recommend buying this during a sale. Thanks for taking the time to read this! Bye!

reviewText: This game is a cool idea for representing some of the most notorious events on the Pewdiepie channel, but the only people who ever gonna buy this are serious bros (like me) who are willing to support felix. All the reviews that I have seen are awful and saying the game shouldn't be bought. I kind of agree with them as it is an arcade game which costs quite a lot for what it is. Once you've completed the game, (which took me about 3 hours doing all the levels and redoing some to get coins) you are not gonna come back as there is not much else to it. I feel this game is a almost a troll and a way to joke about pewdiepie's habits in a video game.  However, I'm not gonna be too harsh about this as it is a decent game while it lasts. The controls feel really stocky though, so I went out and bought a logitech wireless controller but it still felt like the character movement was not fluid. (That was forty quid wasted). The gameplay in general was okay, though. But the game to me is just a joke and isn't worth playing unless you want to support Felix as a bro. Even I find it tiresome, so I would not recommend this even though it's a cheap price it still is too expensive for what it is. When you've gone through the entire game through its frustration, blood and tears, and smashing the controller on your face, thats the end. Better go out and buy a new one. If you want my opinion, don't buy this, go buy gmod or something else. (great game btw).\n
